Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Cellular and Molecular Dissection of "Organizing Activity" during Development in the Spiralia
Award.AbstractNarration:
During normal development, signals between cells in the early embryo can have
substantial influence on how the body develops, such as how the eyes and brain
become localized in the head or how the spinal cord becomes localized on the back and
not the belly. These early events have a tremendous effect on the organization of the
tissues within the body and are critical for normal development of all animals. This
project will determine how changes in early developmental mechanisms can lead to
formation of new body parts. The three study animals are segmented worms, and offer
the advantage that their embryos possess only 16 to 64 cells when these critical early
signaling events occur. This contrasts with the approximately 1000 cells at a comparable
stage in the vertebrate embryo. Thus, development will be studied on the single cell level,
and similar cells can be compared across distantly related animals. The specific goals of
this study are to identify the signaling cell and the molecules responsible for instructing
surrounding cells to correctly position and generate body parts. The proposed study will
provide strong STEM training opportunities by integrating scientific training with research
for college students, graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. In addition, there will
be ongoing community outreach activities, including hands-on activities with several
different K-12 age groups in the local school districts to teach about animal biodiversity
of the oceans, and general talks to adults in the local community.

This project seeks to understand how developmental changes lead to a range of body
plans, and represents a unique opportunity to gain insight into the evolution of
developmental programs. A group of animals known as the Spiralia exhibit enormous
body plan diversity, yet many phyla in this clade share a highly stereotypic embryological
program called spiralian development. This conservation allows studies of the evolution
of homologous embryonic cell lineages with single cell resolution across diverse taxa.
Specifically, the molecular signaling repertoire of a single cell will be determined, and the
evolutionary plasticity of its organizing activity will be assessed by comparing distantly
related species. Spiralian development will be investigated experimentally in the
annelids Capitella teleta, Platynereis dumerilii and Chaetopterus sp. The phylogenetic
position and embryonic studies of the three species will be used to reconstruct the
ancestral cellular and molecular characteristics of annelid organizing activity. Specific
goals of the project utilizing the three annelids are: 1) deletion of single cells in early
stage embryos to identify cell(s) possessing 'organizing activity', 2) identification of
molecular signals that mediate organizing activity, 3) determination of the function of
organizing signals by knockdown and mis-expression studies. The proposed study will
provide strong training opportunities by integrating scientific training with research, and
continue to develop Capitella and Platynereis as annelid models for Evo-Devo studies.
There will be ongoing community outreach activities, including hands-on activities with
several different age groups in the local school districts that highlight biodiversity in the
oceans, and general talks to adult audiences in the local community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this collaborative research project between two laboratories was to elucidate and compare the organizing activity in spiral-cleaving embryos of three species of segmented worms. This laboratory focused its efforts on one of the three species, the annelid Platynereis dumerilii.  The specific goals of this study were to identify the signaling cell in this embryo (the ‘organizer’), and the molecules responsible for instructing surrounding cells (the ‘organizing activity’) to correctly position and generate body parts in this species.

 To do so several experimental techniques and molecular resources had to be developed including deletion of distinct embryonic cells in Platynereis embryos, establishment of developmental gene expression profiles to identify potential candidate signaling molecules, and incubation procedures to inhibit and/or elicit signals. Thus, the study provided profound scientific training opportunities and support for three postdoctoral scholars, three graduate, and more than ten undergraduate students. Individuals acquired significant expertise in bioinformatics, molecular phylogenetics, developmental and cell biology, as well as evo-devo procedures including in situ hybridization to identify and localize transcripts in individual embryonic cells. Students involved in this project successfully applied for medical school, graduate programs in genetics and medical illustration, genetic counseling, and various jobs in biotech and pharmaceutical industry including seed and plant genetics. Comprehensive molecular resources established for this project have been integrated in a publically accessible online research tool enabling unrestricted data mining and extraction for the entire scientific community. 

 Key outcome of this project is the identification of one distinct embryonic cell as the ‘organizer’ in early Platynereis embryos. Deletion of this particular cell caused a dramatic reorganization of the head region in manipulated embryos. Instead of dorsal (front) and ventral (back) tissues within the head region of the larvae, the head comprised of all ventral tissues (a ventralized phenotype).  This suggested that the deleted cell acts indeed as an ‘organizer’ emanating a signal to instruct the neighboring cells from the head region to form dorsal (front) tissue. Furthermore this project identified the molecular nature of the signal that is present in the organizer. Experimentally blocking the signal had the same effect as deleting the ‘organizer’ cell leading to a ventralized larval phenotype. Incubating normal embryos with ectopic signals had the opposite effect leading to a dorsalized larval phenotype. This suggests that the identified signal indeed constitutes the ‘organizing activity’ in early Platynereis embryos instructing neighboring cells to form dorsal head tissue. Intriguingly, the same signaling activity has been shown to be involved in organizer formation to pattern dorsal and ventral tissues in vertebrates and mammal embryos including humans.

 The principal investigator, as well as postdoctoral scholars, graduate students, and undergraduates participated in various activities to educate the public about life cycles of marine organisms including fertilization, embryonic and larval, adult, as well as sexually mature stages. Annual activities included hands on experiences for PreK classes in ‘Ocean’ week, and presentations at ‘Science Night (‘Of fish and worms’) at local elementary schools. Particular successful were Skype-video conferences (one hour long chats) with high school students educating them about the purpose and daily life in a research laboratory while introducing and illustrating a variety of molecular biological techniques and principles that are part of their advanced biology curriculum.
